currentSuggestions: [{'index': 0, 'original': 'When women are in the dating market, it seems that they realize that the only way to compete is to show of their most attractive features.', 'trimmed': 'When women are in the dating market, it seems that they realize that the only way to compete is to show of their most attractive features.', 'probability': 1.0375927417886665e-31}, {'index': 1, 'original': 'Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I\'m good for."', 'trimmed': 'Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I\'m good for."', 'probability': 5.892149983965734e-31}, {'index': 2, 'original': 'Relationships are formed on the basis of looks, convenience, and the ability to communicate via text.', 'trimmed': 'Relationships are formed on the basis of looks, convenience, and the ability to communicate via text.', 'probability': 2.743610822350173e-29}, {'index': 3, 'original': 'It promotes an idea that one is always looking for better options.', 'trimmed': 'It promotes an idea that one is always looking for better options.', 'probability': 3.005371563443841e-41}, {'index': 4, 'original': 'In dating, it is easy to judge people on things like race and body type.', 'trimmed': 'In dating, it is easy to judge people on things like race and body type.', 'probability': 1.0569038887971073e-31}]

currentDoc:
How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for."

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for."

currentDoc:
How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

currentDoc:
How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.


We lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".

currentDoc:
How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplac

It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions.

currentDoc:
How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person.

currentDoc:
How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set.

 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

currentDoc:
How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.

 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.

 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
  It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression. We are so far removed from natural human contact, and our sense of security and well being are suffering because of it.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions.

 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

Technology has encouraged superficiality, d

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

Technology has encouraged superficiality, dishonesty, and l

It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

Technology has encouraged superficiality, dishonesty, and lack of commit

We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.

It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

Technology has encouraged superficiality, dishonesty, and lack of commitment. Perhaps it's time to turn off our scree

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." It promotes a shallowness in which we can glance over the person and make a judgment of them based on their profile picture, or how they present themselves on a dating app.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

Technology has encouraged superficiality, dishonesty, and lack of commitment. Perhaps it's time to turn off our screens and get back to meeting people the old-fashioned way.   Afe're losing touch with how wonderful the simple pleasures of human contact can be.

 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

Technology has encouraged superficiality, dishonesty, and lack of commitment. Perhaps it's time to turn off our screens and get back to meeting people the old-fashioned way.   After all, we do losing touch with how wonderful the simple pleasures of human contact can be.

 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

Technology has encouraged superficiality, dishonesty, and lack of commitment. Perhaps it's time to turn off our screens and get back to meeting people the old-fashioned way.   After all, we don't want to lose touch with how wonderful the simple pleasures of human contact can be.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

Technology makes dating worse. It promotes a superficial and shallow view of people as commodities. Rather than seeing people as complex and wonderful, we are presented with a limited and basic message that says, "here is what I'm good for." echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it curat and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

Technology has encouraged superficiality, dishonesty, and lack of commitment. It's time to turn off our screens and get back to meeting people the old-fashioned way.   After all, we don't want to lose touch with how wonderful the simple pleasures of human contact can be.

 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it curating their own  and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

Technology has encouraged superficiality, dishonesty, and lack of commitment. It's time to turn off our screens and get back to meeting people the old-fashioned way.   After all, we don't want to lose touch with how wonderful the simple pleasures of human contact can be.

e lose opportunities to have real, meaningful, in-depth relationships where we can get to know someone in the "slow lane".
  aking time to get to know someone is more meaningful than simply swiping right or left on a dating app.
 Technology also encourages dishonesty and being manipulative, especially with how easy it is to delete or avoid people on social media and dating apps.  "Ghosting" is commonplace-you don't feel like listening? Just never reply back, no explanation needed, zero repercussions. 

echnology seems to replace real, deep relationships with superficial ones.
 Because there is such a rapid decline in value of one's interactions on social media, one spends more time on it curating their own perfect image and less time searching for a real relationship with another person. A lot of people act like movie characters, piecing together a picture of themselves that they wish was true, rather than expressing who they truly are.
AManypeople seem to be on the hunt for perfection in the things and people they idolize.
 They are constantly comparing others to a perfect image they have created in their minds or a standard they've set. On social media and dating apps, you see constant comparisons and negativity. Nothing is ever good enough, or someone is always doing better than you.
We focus on finding attention, likes, good pics-instead of finding real, meaningful people to relate to.
   We are so far removed from natural human contact, our sense of security and well-being are suffering because of it. It's no wonder why there's an increase in anxiety and depression.

Technology has encouraged superficiality, dishonesty, and lack of commitment. It's time to turn off our screens and get back to meeting people the old-fashioned way.   After all, we don't want to lose touch with how wonderful the simple pleasures of human contact can be.
